If you‚Äôre feeling that pang of nostalgia ‚Äúthe old days with friends‚Äù this game really scratches that itch. The unplanned moments, the shared laughter when someone misreads a map, the scramble to plug holes mid-storm‚Ä¶ these are the moments you remember, not the grind.

"10% of this game is sailing‚Ä¶ the other 90% is screaming at skeletons." 

11/10  <3.

[h3]Rating: 95/100[/h3]
[h2]A Pirate Adventure I Never Expected to Love[/h2]

I honestly never thought I‚Äôd enjoy Sea of Thieves this much. The visuals are absolutely stunning, and there are so many different ways to play the game.

There‚Äôs always something new to explore, whether you‚Äôre questing, PvPing, fishing, hunting for secrets, or just vibing on the ocean. I do wish they‚Äôd add a bit more quality-of-life‚Äîlike better ship d√©cor customization or easier barrel sorting‚Äîbut those are tiny complaints in comparison to how much the game offers.

Its replayability is insane. You can easily sink hundreds or even thousands of hours without running out of things to do. A truly amazing co-op experience.

An utterly melancholy diversion full of scoundrells and black guards, but the pleasure and satisfaction of teaching them a lesson and dancing rigadoon steps on their quartedeck is unlike anything one can imagine.
straight up the most beautiful game, everything just looks perfect and the sound design is crazy good, really fun to play with a group of friends, plundering ships n' all.

Malheureusement, les devs sont plus pr√©occup√©s a pondre des skins dans l'emporium que de patch tous les bugs qui durent depuis des ann√©es...
Pour ne pas aider, le jeu est pollu√© par les cheaters qui soit disant se vengent que Rare ai stopp√© le mode de jeux de l'ar√®ne (TDM)... Path√©tique mais r√©el...

Le jeu est as son prime et as encore tellement a donner (avec ses nouvelles saisons tous les 3-4 mois) mais il se meurt tout doucement...

Sea of Thieves: Sail to a Free Pirate Carnival, With Waves as Your Anthem

In an era flooded with open-world games, Sea of Thieves stands out as an irreplaceable multiplayer masterpiece, thanks to its unique "pirate simulator" identity. Rare Ltd. has polished this game for seven years, turning a vast, boundless ocean into a stage brimming with adventures and laughter‚Äîhere, there are no constraints of linear storylines or mandatory KPIs, only sails, waves, and companions, allowing every player to live out an unshackled pirate dream.

The core charm of the game lies in its perfect blend of the romance and down-to-earth warmth of "pirate life." You can team up with 1-3 friends, starting with a small, agile sloop and working your way up to commanding a majestic galleon. Every ship requires precise teamwork to sail: one person steers the helm to align the course, another climbs the masts to adjust the sails, someone guards the cannons against surprise attacks, and another manages supplies in the hold. Even working together to bail seawater out of the ship‚Äôs bottom is filled with immersive collaborative joy. The ocean itself is a vivid character‚Äîmorning sun dyes the sea golden-red, evening glow casts sparkling ripples, sudden storms whip up towering waves that make the ship lurch dangerously, and lightning on rainy nights illuminates the outline of a mysterious island in the distance. The realistic sound of waves, the howl of sails, and the shouts of the crew blend together; closing your eyes and listening makes you feel as if you‚Äôre truly standing on the deck of a heaving pirate ship.

The freedom of exploration and adventure makes every voyage full of unexpected surprises. You can take on delivery quests from the Merchant Alliance, shuttling between islands for trade; follow clues on treasure maps to dig up long-buried chests with a shovel; or challenge the sea monster Kraken, fighting for survival amid its thrashing tentacles. The island designs are full of ingenuity: dense jungles hide abandoned pirate camps, deep caves have glowing springs flowing through them, and ancient temples are filled with traps‚Äîevery landing might reveal a new secret. The game‚Äôs most touching aspect is undoubtedly "aimless wandering"‚Äîput aside quests, let the ship drift with the waves, land on an unnamed island, collect seashells, build sandcastles, or light a bonfire by the shore to share the "spoils" you‚Äôve plundered. This slow-paced romance is why many players become obsessed with the game.

Multiplayer is the soul of Sea of Thieves, as well as the source of both joy and controversy. Times spent teaming up with friends are always filled with laughter: accidentally firing a cannon and blowing a teammate into the sea, bickering while fighting over the ship‚Äôs wheel, panicking when chased by another pirate ship, and cheering wildly after successfully repelling enemies. These shared moments are the game‚Äôs most precious memories. However, the mandatory PVP mechanism once deterred many new players‚Äîjust after collecting a full load of treasure chests, you might be ambushed by an experienced pirate crew, losing all the supplies you worked so hard to gather, or even encountering hostile taunters or cheaters, which seriously ruins the gaming experience. Fortunately, the developers have continued to optimize the game over time: they not only introduced a new player protection system but also plan to launch a PVE mode for players to transition smoothly, ensuring that players of all skill levels can find their own fun.

Seven years of continuous updates have kept this ocean vibrant. From the original basic gameplay to later additions like the "Pirate Legend" career, large-scale expansions such as "Forsaken Shores," and various holiday events and character customization systems, Rare Ltd. has constantly added new content, making the pirate world increasingly rich. The low-poly art style may seem simple, but it perfectly matches the relaxed tone of ocean adventures‚Äîbright, colorful visuals and cute character designs ensure that even intense sea battles never feel oppressive.

Sea of Thieves is never a perfect game; it has flaws like repetitive quests and somewhat thin endgame content. But the unique experience it offers is irreplaceable. It is more than just a game‚Äîit is a social stage. Here, what you gain is not just virtual treasure, but the friendship of fighting side-by-side with friends, the surprise of exploring the unknown, and the sense of freedom from breaking free of constraints. For players who love multiplayer games and yearn for a pirate‚Äôs life, this ocean is always open, waiting for you to hoist the sails and write your own pirate legend.
its a good game but you kind of have to play it with friends for it to be fun. This isn't a bad thing its just something to keep in mind if you buy it.

For years, *Sea of Thieves* was more than just a game to me ‚Äî it was a distant dream. I watched gameplay videos, trailers, and streamers sail the open seas, fight skeletons, and hunt for treasure, wishing I could experience it myself. I didn‚Äôt have the money to buy it back then, so all I could do was imagine what it would feel like to step onto a pirate ship and call it my own.

Then one of my friends gifted it to me.

That moment meant more than just receiving a game ‚Äî it was like being handed a key to a world I had been locked out of for years. Finally loading it up for the first time was honestly one of the best gaming moments I‚Äôve ever had.

**Sea of Thieves** isn‚Äôt just about pirates ‚Äî it‚Äôs about freedom, adventure, chaos, teamwork, and those unexpected moments that turn into unforgettable stories. The ocean is beautiful and dangerous at the same time. One minute you‚Äôre calmly sailing under a golden sunset, and the next you‚Äôre fighting a kraken or trying to outmaneuver another crew hunting you down. No two sessions are ever the same.

The art style is unique and colorful, and the ocean physics are some of the best I‚Äôve seen in any game. The way waves move, how storms feel real, and the sound of wooden planks creaking under a battle makes everything incredibly immersive. You don‚Äôt just *play* Sea of Thieves ‚Äî you *live in it*.

But what truly makes the game special is the experience with friends (or even strangers). Whether we‚Äôre laughing while failing to park the ship properly or screaming as enemy cannons rain down on us, every moment becomes a story worth remembering. It taught me teamwork, patience, and how to stay calm in absolute chaos.

Now that I can finally play it myself, I realize **Sea of Thieves was worth every second of waiting**. This isn‚Äôt just a game anymore ‚Äî it‚Äôs a personal victory, a reminder that sometimes dreams do come true, even in the smallest form: a gifted copy of a pirate game.

And honestly?

It‚Äôs one of the best gifts I‚Äôve ever received. ‚öìüè¥‚ò†Ô∏è

Sea of Thieves is a magical experience where you and your friends set out to become legendary pirates‚Ä¶ and usually end up sinking yourselves before anyone else even shows up.

This game taught me:
I can‚Äôt steer, My friends can‚Äôt read maps, and none of us should ever be trusted near gunpowder barrels.

The ocean is gorgeous‚Äîseriously, the waves look so good I‚Äôve crashed into rocks just admiring them. Multiple times. Every session.

PvP is pure chaos. One moment you‚Äôre singing shanties and raising sails, the next you‚Äôre being boarded by a sweaty 12-year-old who parkours onto your ship, steals your bananas, and sets everything on fire.

The treasure hunts? Amazing.
Finding the treasure? Simple.
Getting the treasure back to an outpost without Kraken attacks, mega-sharks, storms, or your own crewmate launching themselves out of a cannon ‚Äúto scout ahead‚Äù? Impossible.

The perfect game for people who want to be pirates without any of the competence required to actually be pirates.

Sea of Thieves is a unique and high-quality game that offers a true pirate experience like no other. The game is constantly updated with new content, making the adventure even more exciting. [h2]‚öìSummary‚öì[/h2]
Sea of Thieves is a chaotic, freedom-filled pirate sandbox where every voyage becomes an unpredictable story. It thrives on cooperation, exploration and adventure quests but it isn‚Äôt always friendly to solo players or those who want structured content.

[h2] Pros‚úÖ[/h2]
üåä Beautiful world with stunning oceans and vibrant islands.
üè¥‚ò†Ô∏è Player-driven adventures every session feels unique.
ü§ù Great co-op experience especially with friends.
ü™ô Lots of cosmetics and progression without pay-to-win.
üéµ Amazing soundtrack and fun pirate vibes.
üß≠ Guided quests for players.

[h2] Cons‚ùå[/h2]
‚öîÔ∏è Unpredictable PvP can ruin casual sessions.
üö∂ Solo play is tough especially against groups.

[h2] Verdict [/h2]
Sea of Thieves shines when you play with a coordinated crew, turning chaos into memorable pirate stories. It‚Äôs not perfect but its charm, freedom and atmosphere make it a standout co-op adventure.

[h2] Rating [/h2] 9.8 / 10

[h2] Best Forüë•[/h2]
Players who love open-world co-op adventures.
Gamers who enjoy sandbox games and creating their own fun.
People who like PvP-optional exploration with friends.
Anyone who wants to role-play as a pirate and cause trouble.

Game is fun, with no two sessions being same. However there are a few things that you should know.
1. You have to be ok with sinking. I know it sucks, but it will happen. At the end of day it is just virtual coin
2. Dont set out with a plan in mind. Just set sail and see where the voyage takes you. odds are you will have more fun and get more gold
3. some ppl will be toxic. Ignore them.
4. playing with others is always more fun. If you have no one to play with join a Sea Thieves discord or another social platform. They have entire area dedicated to those looking for a crew. avoid open crew
5. Do not fear pvp. Sometimes you should go into fights just for the practice. You wont get good if you dont try to
6. play for fun, not to get gold
7. when parking you want your sails and anchor up. this way if a crew pulls up you can quick drop sails and get moving
8. people can and will betray alliances. you can still make them and have fun together, but keep and eye out
9. not all pistol skins are accurate, you can go on yt to see which ones are, or use a crosshair overly app
10.(optional) record your gameplay because random stuff happens a bunch and it is usaully funny

Join game during Gold And Glory, Sloop, just wanna grind money for pirate lord

Speedrun skelly Fort as fast as humanly possible and finish it getting chest of legend and athena
Look upon the horizon to see a galleon is going at full speed with wind
look only the important stuff an skeddadle as fast as possible to my ship and use spare horn of winds to start up the boat
Run
Sell athena and legend from a driveby at top left port
sail across the map in a clockwise way all while backboarding the whole time.
manage to keg the galleon, giving me enough time to sell around 100,000k worth of stuff
The captained burning blade comes to my rescue after i run the bottom of the map sinking the galleon,
i sell all my stuff and get hunted down by the galleon
they called me a runner
im ~500,000k richer and they wasted 1 hour chasing me for nothing
my heartrate spiked to 200 i will never top that

*"This game has been out for a while. The team is well past the debut of their creative baby, but being the good parents they are, these devs continue to nurture and support their creation. This game, to this day, is still getting new content after all these years."*

There are very few games left that fits this category so perfectly. So please, follow Rare Ltd's lead and show some love to the best pirate game, OAT.  They deserve it.

Sea of Thieves delivers a lively and adventurous voyage across a vibrant open ocean, offering an experience shaped by exploration and unpredictable encounters. The game immediately establishes a sense of freedom, inviting players to sail in any direction and discover hidden treasures or sudden dangers. Its world feels alive, with dynamic weather and emergent events ensuring no two sessions unfold the same. The overall tone celebrates shared adventure and spontaneous storytelling.
The narrative structure in Sea of Thieves remains intentionally loose, encouraging players to craft their own stories through the quests and world events encountered along the way. Tall Tales offer more directed, lore driven experiences, weaving charming pirate fantasy with light mystery and puzzle solving. Across these journeys, the sense of being part of a grand maritime legend never fades. This flexible approach to storytelling supports both casual exploration and deeper engagement.
Gameplay focuses heavily on co operation, rewarding crews that communicate and coordinate effectively. Sailing feels tactile and responsive, with every task from raising the anchor to trimming the sails demanding attention. Combat, whether against skeleton hordes or rival crews, brings exhilarating tension enhanced by the constant threat of losing hard earned loot. The blend of naval manoeuvring, exploration, and combat keeps the experience varied and engaging.
Visually, Sea of Thieves impresses with its striking water simulation and expressive, colourful art style. The ocean serves as the star, capturing storms, sunsets, and reflections with remarkable beauty. Character and creature designs embrace a whimsical, cartoon inspired aesthetic that complements the adventurous tone. The world‚Äôs vibrant presentation enhances the sense of escapism and discovery.
Overall, Sea of Thieves stands as an engaging and visually captivating pirate adventure that thrives on shared experiences and emergent storytelling. Its flexible narrative structure, polished sailing mechanics, and vibrant presentation create a compelling world to explore. While its open ended design may rely heavily on player driven moments, it consistently rewards curiosity and teamwork. The result is a memorable seafaring experience filled with charm and excitement.
Sea of Thieves gets a 7/10.

For more reviews check my Steam profile
Hope you enjoyed my review, god bless you

negative.review:
A phenomenal concept, executed almost right. If you seek exploration and adventure you've come to the right place. However, the game suffers from a glaring flaw: Trolling. 
Rare is deadset on making sure all the content rewards PVP and discourages adventure.  Each update they push seems to ensure that try-hard players get rewarded and casual players get punished.

Pros:
Adventure
Loot
Beautiful graphics
Achievements for completionists
Many locations to explore
Great with friends
Updates add new exciting content

Cons:
Rare is more concerned with retaining the more toxic playerbase demographic than it is with the more casual players.
Discouraged from playing the safer seas mode. 
Updates hinder new/casual players and reward those who discourage others from playing at all.

Most of these issues could be solved if Rare would;
>Allow emissary in safer seas. Gold is for cosmetics, you dont need to discourage players from a mode they enjoy more.
>Undo the recent weapon swap speed update, this was an abysmally bad idea.
>Allow in-game reporting that auto-submits the previous 5-10 minutes of footage. Forcing players to screen record and go through your website makes it difficult to prove abuse, when it is not communicated to them how to report beforehand. (This one is GLARINGLY important.)
Having to sign into a Microsoft account to play the game is upsetting enough. It then breaking and requiring some troubleshooting is worthy of a negative review in my opinion.

Charging 26 aud for a audio upgrade & a single coconut Headset cosmetic.. nothing like corporate greedy.

Edit; just found out if wanna use the upgrade audio you MUST complete a FACIAL scan of your face & ear's in order to utilise.

The players make the difference. I've tried playing on Open Seas and have consistently ran into nothing but people who'll jump at the chance to ruin your day and take your loot. I'm sure the community was fun and welcoming at some point, but hearing a child yell slurs at you with a megaphone is not my idea of a fun game. Rare doesn't seem to care to do anything about it, because this is still a cash cow for Xbox, the publisher.

Playing on closed seas, even with a full crew feels....empty and lonely? I don't know, I see plenty on content creators showing off fantastic teamwork and wholesome player interactions. For me, in the 120 hours on Game Pass and 15 hours on Steam, I've had one awesome Portuguese crew that helped us hunt Megs and dozens of parasites who'd rather ruin your run then put in the work themselves.

I wish I could leave a neutral review, but Steam demands a Yes or No.

chargin 20 bucks for self-proclaimed improved audio is nasty
edit: upon trying the free trial, it seems everything sounds muffled and i cant actually tell if any aspect of the sound is better. i believe we should blunderbomb someone
the PvP sucks ass and isnt for new and returning players and it ruins the fun

The game play loop on this game is addictive but it has one of the most toxic communities out there. It's not even a gatekeeping thing or a proof of skill, they will hunt you down with the express purpose of ruining your time. I was playing solo and got jumped by a crew of 4 that spent 10 minutes killing me as I spawned. Not so they could do some PvP (which I hate anyway) or to steal my stuff. It was just to make me mad cause they were calling me slurs and spamming emotes at the same time. This is the best game you should never play.

Developers are hell bent on catering to a audience no one else wants to play with. Any type of push for a full PvE option is an insult to this "community" because they do not want PvP they want to harass people trying to have fun. Finally, when they seem to change course releasing a PvE mode, they spit in the face of everyone wanting it by releasing a crippled version for no reason other then to feed into another game mode those seeking PvE do not even want. Rather then printing money from a cosmetic shop backed by strong content like Grinding Gear Games, or a plethora of other competent companies they would rather die on their hill. Good news is, with the current consistent loss of players, next year they will have a PvE mode, because it will be a single player game.

I have well over 1500 hours on this game. I love the game its self but the toxic people that spawn camp constantly and yell constant slurs just ruin any fun you might have. The general over all toxic player base is why cannot recommend this game. I have met some awesome people but a good 90% of players i come across are just bad people. I even grew up in cod lobbies. its not just yelling to yell its its just bad people.

In all honesty I love this game, I started playing this back in season 4. However, this game has been recently plagued by some pretty annoying issues. I was never one for pvp, anytime the devs try to make serious changes to pvp the loud minority of player wine until the meta is reestablished. The current issue with pvp in sea of thieves is not that it is hard but that it is boring, the tactics are flushed out and all battle basically devolve into get on their ship and drop the anchor. The second big issue is the player base in general, every time I play the game i either am fighting someone screaming racial slurs, a literal child, or someone with the pvp skins who have clearly played more hours then me. Now I know what your thinking just get gud, play more hours and pvp, well here's the thing I don't want to and apparently considering the dwindling player count no one else does either. Even if I did I pretty much run into cheaters every time I play. Alternatively rare has included a team sever mode, which is great but due to the how much your loot drops are nerfed combined with no multipliers that mode isn't very fulfiling. This caused the player spike when the mode was released to be very short lived. Not to mention the most recent tall tales sucked. 

To summarize:
Cheaters, sweats, and murder hobos ruined pvp
hour glass is full of cheaters
PVP is to linear and always plays the same
A team server that is less restrictive would actually sustain the player spike
PVP players will argue that the game got worse when the solo mode was added, they are lying it is a disingenuous argument that suits their desire to fight someone who doesn't want to. There were large player spikes when the mode was added and the main complaint was it was to restrictive, the less restrictive form nerfed loot drops and did not allow for meaningful progression. 
Would I recommend this game, nope, games player count is on the decline and unlike in season 4 solo slooping no longer feels doable.

I could only play for about an hour. Due to it being first person view, and the nature of the game, made me extremely motion sick.

Really there needs to be a neutral review option, I wouldn't recommend or not recommend this game. Just be ware that if you get motion sick, this game may not be for you.

Save your money. This game will nonstop spam you with asshole players constantly attacking you when they know for a fact that you are a new player since you start with a shit ship and wearing shit rags. This game will also nonstop spam you with a nonstop mob spawning that will not allow you turn in even your first ever fucking quest.

Before you buy :)

Can I play this while having a job

Yes. The game does not really keep long term progression. When you log out the only things that stay are your gold and the ship you purchased. All loot like cannonballs and food disappears. Good for players who cannot commit every day.

Are you a PVP player

If you enjoy PVP this game is very fun. Everyone has the same gear so skill is what matters. No pay to win and no advantage for older players. Just get good.

Can I play this every day

You can but expect the game to feel repetitive.
After reaching Pirate Legend you have basically completed the main goal. Everything after that is for cosmetics titles and achievements. These do not help in combat. Flexing on hoes is what matter at this point.

PVP Experience

Outside Hourglass fights a normal ship battle can last 30 minutes to 1 hour depending on the players and the ship sizes. Sometimes you will fight two players or even four players while you are alone or with one friend. This can be exciting or frustrating. Just get good.

PVE Experience

Megalodon is scary the first time but after a few encounters it becomes simple. Just sail to the nearest island and it will disappear. Kraken is not really threatening. The water becomes dark you cant sail just fight not really hard. Skeleton ships and storms annoying you can sail around the storm just annoying since you delaying going to your destination for skeleton ship the loot is okay but not amazing. World events are a mix of PVP and PVE but nothing too special after a while.

My Thoughts

Sea of Thieves is very fun with friends but boring alone unless you want cosmetics or achievements.

Traveling takes most of the play time. You will sail for around five minutes or more for every island. A single quest can take two to three hours and more than 60% of that is just sailing with nothing happening.

Crew limit is four players. You can form alliances to make groups. I myself played with 8 people you can do this by sever hopping and spawning with a galleon until at least 2 play from your team find a match on the same server. This is fun when you are part of it but not fun for everyone else.

Pets

Pets look nice but they do nothing helpful.
It would be better if monkeys fed you or if dogs helped you find treasure faster. Right now pets are only for looks and nothing else.

Battle Pass

You can earn Ancient Coins without buying the pass but it is very rare.

Final Verdict

Sea of Thieves is amazing with friends but becomes repetitive fast.
Great for players who enjoy PVP and want a relaxed sailing adventure.
Not great for players who want strong progression or deep PVE.

Honestly any game that has to have its files verified and the game basically redownloaded due to their anti-cheat engine breaking isnt worth much as far as playing. At least half my playtime is running the game for it to crash, not sign me in at all, or sitting in the menu trying to get the games audio to even come close to working. Beautiful game on the eyes and whatever optimization they did recently is great for the framerate and overall smoothness of the game itself, but between the horrid player base (weve all been chased down for a few cannonballs and bananas, havent we?) and the game itself not really working half the time, its not worth the price tag it comes with and its most certainly not worth the price tag of the trinkets and knicknacks and season passes. If you can get this game for 5 bucks thats great, but youll be pretty pissed once you keep having to take the time to verify, download, and install its game data 3 hours a month as well. Id say "have fun" but before the toxic player base makes you bitter the crashes will piss you off first.

I could not get the game to respect my settings and not use hands free calling for my wireless Headset. 
For those who don't know this results in horrible Audio quality since Bluethooth is not capable of handling high quality In and output at the same time. Just imaginge putting your phone in a tin can and put the volume to max. Then you know how this sounds. This is not an issue in any other game I own. Every game respects not using the Headset mic how its set up in windows.

Deactivation all other devices besides my USB mic and Headphones did not work. 
Changing gamebar and xbox settings to use the Headphones for just output and the usb mic for input did not work. 
Deactiviating Hands Free mode via windows resulted in no audio at all. 

The game always forced the hdeadphones to be used in hands free mode resulting in horrible audio quality for the whole system. 

After trying everything i could find online about fixing it and nothing working i just gave up and refunded without playing a single second.  I wasted over an hour researching and messing with settings without success. 

Sad that a mircrosoft related company can not get their product to work properly with their own operating system.

Surely we arent expected to google every single thing we do or want to do, how boring.
